title: The Only 3 Things Parents Should Do During Math Time
description: Stop doing too much. Here's what actually helps vs. what hurts your child's math learning.
imageAlt: Parent appropriately supporting child's math learning

content.intro: Most parents do too much during math time. They explain, correct, push, hover. Here's the surprising truth: less is more.

sections.text: Sit nearby. Be available. But don't watch every keystroke. Your presence provides security; hovering creates pressure.
What this looks like: You're reading a book in the same room while they practice. They know you're there if they need you.
Acknowledge effort, not results. "You're working hard." "I see you're focusing." Not "That's wrong" or "Be careful!"
What this looks like: When they finish, you say "Nice work today!" not "Let me check if you got them right."
Your job is to make sure practice happens, not to teach the math. Same time, same duration, every day. That's it.
What this looks like: "It's 4:00, math time." Period. No debate about whether they feel like it.
If you're exhausted after math time, you're probably doing too much. It should be low-effort for you.

rows: Creates dependency, removes struggle (where learning happens)
Prevents them from self-correcting and learning from errors

items: [They practice, you're nearby but not hovering]

sections.text: That's it. No lectures. No reviews. No drama. The app or program teaches; you provide the structure.

faq.question: What if they're getting lots of problems wrong?
faq.answer: Let the app provide feedback. That's what it's for. If consistent struggles continue for days, the level might need adjusting â€“ that's when to step in.

faq.question: Should I check their answers afterward?
faq.answer: Only if you can do it without turning it into a teaching moment or criticism. A glance at the progress report is fine; going through each error is too much.

faq.question: What if I know better ways to solve the problems?
faq.answer: Keep them to yourself unless asked. Different methods confuse kids. Trust the app's approach.
